messages.subject: Fwd: Nagamaki
messages.msgSnippet: Alan - Tried sending this to Topica but my messages don t get through... Tom Helm toryu@toryu-mon.com Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus - Vergil ...
messages.messageBody:
Alan -
Tried sending this to Topica but my messages don't get through...
Tom Helm
toryu@...
"Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus"
- Vergil



Begin forwarded message:

> From: Tom Helm <toryu@...>
> Date: July 10, 2011 11:42:59 AM PDT
> To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
> Subject: Re: Nagamaki
>
> Alan -
> At 33" a terrific sword and a terrific find as I said. I have to
> agree with chris this is looking more like a Shinshin-to piece and
> based on the few photos we have a Satsuma piece. He is thinking of
> Jigen Ryu and the profile of this tsuka certainly fits their
> standards, the small tsuba as well. The saya is a bit of an enigma
> since there appear to be no other fittings which might have provided
> some confirmation of that idea.
> I will agree with Barry as well the size and length of the
> blade, the deep hamachi and mune-machi, the ubu-ba that you report,
> the mottled
> colour of the nakago and the presence of a shinobi-ana all suggest
> later manufacture. So Shinshin-to it is.
> This is some find, and I would love to see more photos when you've
> the chance. Thank you for posting it and stirring up the
> conversation...
> -t
> Tom Helm
> toryu@...
> "Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus"
> - Vergil
>
>
>
> On Jul 10, 2011, at 3:24 AM, Barry Thomas wrote:
>
>> Is anybody else having trouble with the eSnips downloader??? I
>> download it and can't get a copy of the file to view it. I'm going
>> to uninstall it and not bother - BUT - I would have said:
>> - big blade
>> - big ububa
>> - big machi
>> = Shinshinto blade.
>>
>> FWIW looking at thumbnails...
>>
>> Regards,
>> Barry Thomas.
>> ----- Original Message -----
>> From: abale.vossnet.co.uk
>> To: Nihonto Study ; Token Kenkyu-kai
>> Sent: Saturday, July 09, 2011 10:37 PM
>> Subject: Nagamaki
>>
>> Amazingly at a London auction last week I purchased what I think is
>> a late Muromachi/Momoyama period nagamaki in its original koshirae.
>> The heavy 32.75" blade is unsigned but inscribed �ichi� as are the
>> yamagane fuchi, koi-guchi and one seppa, the open end of the tsuka
>> is similarly marked in ink under the fuchi. The tsuba is 16th
>> century Tachi-kanagushi work lacquered red and may be original to
>> the mounting.
>>
>> The blade is too discoloured to see any details but it has ububa of
>> 7" and the edge side of the habaki has a slot cut into it to allow
>> for this.
>>
>> I assume this is the first of a group of similarly mounted weapons
>> ordered by a clan or Temple. I think that the sword has been kept
>> in storage for a very long time as it is not for everyday use,
>> weighing around 6lbs and is 4'7" long overall and is in mostly good
>> condition but with worm holes in the leather bound tsuka
>>
>> I would like to know if anyone on the list has seen a similarly
>> mounted nagamaki, the black sam� and red lacquered binding are
>> distinctive. I would like to know where it came from.
>>
>> I have uploaded images at:
>> http://www.esnips.com/web/TsubaFittings
>> --^^---------------------------------------------------------------
>> This email was sent to: toryu@...
>>
